fields.descriptive_line: John Constable, Netley Abbey, with Southampton Water in the background, 1816, Reynolds cat. no. 150
fields.physical_description: Pencil drawing of Netley Abbey, surrounded by trees and water.
fields.title: Netley Abbey, with Southampton Water in the background
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level F, case WD, shelf 17
Prints & Drawings Study Room, level F

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level F

fields.bibliography: Catalogue of the Constable Collection, Graham Reynolds, Victoria and Albert Museum, London: HMSO, 1973, pp. 110, 112, 114 The following is an extract from the text of the entry: There is no evidence to show that this drawing came from a sketch-book, but it was in all probability made at the same time as Nos. 147-149 [823-1888, 268-1888, 606-1888, 613-1888]. Beckett points out (Connoisseur. loc. cit, p. 4, note) that a drawing sold at Messrs. Sotheby's on 4 may 1949 was said to be of Netley Abbey and dated 20 May 1823: but there is no likelihood that Constable revisited this part of the country at that period. Notes on Nos. 147-154 [823-1888, 268-1888, 606-1888, 613-1888, 311-1888, 628-1888, 303-1888, 791-1888] Nos. 147-154 [see above] were all drawn by Constable on his honeymoon. He was married by John Fisher at St. Martin’s-in-the-Fields on 2 October, and Fisher has invited the newly-married couple to stay at his vicarage at Osmington on the coast near Weymouth, in Dorsetshire. The visit to Netley Abbey on 11 October, when Nos. 147 to 149 [823-1888, 268-1888, 606-1888] and probably also No. 150 [613-1888] were made, was probably undertaken from Southampton on the way down. As Beckett suggests (Connoisseur, loc. cit.) the map on the back of No. 148 [268-1888] would be of use in journeying from Southampton to Osmington, and may also suggest a break of Journey at Ringwood. The latest recorded date for a drawing made at Osmington is that on the back of our drawing No. 153 [303-1888] of 1 December. No. 147 [823-1888] is drawn in the smaller sketch-book which Constable had used earlier in the year, from which No. 146 [233-1888] also comes. Although the hinge marks and the other obvious signs have been trimmed off Nos. 148, 149 [268-1888, 606-1888], and Nos. 151-154 [311-1888, 628-1888, 303-1888, 791-1888], there can be little doubt that these six sheets once formed part of the same sketch-book. The trimming and cutting up of the sketch-book seems in this instance to have been carried out by the artist himself, since the inscriptions on the larger sketch-book pages on to which some of them are mounted (Nos. 149 [606-1888], 153 [303-1888] and 154 [791-1888]) are almost certainly in his hand. Among other drawings which may come from the same sketch-book are: ‘View of Osmington and the Downs with the figure of George III on horseback at Sutton Poyntz’ (4 5/16 x 7 ins.) which was Lot 93 in the Gregory sale, 20 July 1949; ‘Portland Roads’ (4 7/8 x 7 ins.), then in the collection of R.B. Beckett (Connoisseur, loc. cit., fig. VII). In the article cited Beckett discusses other drawings and oil sketches made at the time. See also Beckett, VI, pp. 30-1 and plate 5. An oil sketch of the coast with Portland Island in the distance, similar to the pencil drawings Nos. 151 [311-1888], 152 [628-1888], 154 [791-1888], and 154a [791-1888], is in the City Art Museum, St. Louis (reproduced in the Bulletin of that Museum, Vol. XIV, 1929, p. 8)
fields.historical_context_note:
In 1816 Constable exhibited 'The Wheatfield' and 'A Wood: Autumn' at the Royal Academy.  His father died on 14 May.  He spent some of the summer in Suffolk and paid two visits to Wivenhoe.  He was married by his friend John Fisher to Miss Bicknell on 2 October at St. Martin's-in-the-Fields, and they spent part of the honeymoon staying with Fisher at his vicarage at Osmington, Dorsetshire.

[G Reynolds, 1973, p. 110]
